en_results_raw: <output>the biting wind that blew insistently round the corners of Victory Square, sat in his smallish office at the Ministry of Truth. The telescreen, as usual, blared the morning announcements, a relentless stream of propaganda that filled the air with the Party's voice. Winston's mind, however, was not on the words echoing from the device. Instead, it was occupied with the peculiar anomaly he had noticed earlier that day – the clocks striking thirteen. This was impossible, a clear violation of the Party's strict adherence to the orthodoxy of time. Yet, there it was, a glaring inconsistency that gnawed at his consciousness, a tiny crack in the seamless facade of the Party's control.

en_results: He froze, his heart pounding. The betrayal was unthinkable. The words scrawled across the pages were a direct challenge to the Party's omnipotent slogan. Winston knew that possession of such a
en_results_raw: He froze, his heart pounding. The betrayal was unthinkable. The words scrawled across the pages were a direct challenge to the Party's omnipotent slogan. Winston knew that possession of such a document was a crime punishable by death. His mind raced, contemplating the consequences of being caught. The diary, his clandestine repository of truth and rebellion, was now an incriminating piece of evidence. He had to act fast. With a swift motion, he closed the diary, shoved it into his jacket pocket, and turned the doorknob, stepping out into the corridor as if nothing were amiss. The hallway was eerily silent, the oppressive atmosphere of the Ministry of Truth weighing heavily on his shoulders. He forced himself to walk with casual indifference, though his insides were a tumultuous storm of fear and resolve. The danger was palpable; every footstep echoed with the potential for discovery. Winston knew he had to be more careful than ever. The Party's eyes were everywhere, and their reach was long. He had to find a way to dispose of the diary, to erase this evidence of his disloyalty, before it was too late. The stakes were higher than ever, and the path ahead was fraught with peril. Yet, the thought of erasing his thoughts, of surrendering to the Party's lies, was an anathema he could not bear. He had crossed a line, and there was no turning back. The struggle for truth, for the freedom to think and feel, was now his life's mission, no matter the cost.

en_results_raw: he could not reconstruct an accurate picture of his own infancy. But there were dim fragments of memory which he was quite certain of. There was a certain day, in ever so early childhood, when he had been wandering by himself through the playground with a blocked-up nose. The details of what had happened were very vague, but a certain incident stood out in his memory. He had found—what was it?—a strange thing, a fossil, a small round object that was soft to the touch and seemed to grow like a flower when you squeezed it. Fascinated, he had watched it open out in his hand, revealing a complicated and delicate structure of colored veining inside. For a moment he had a peculiar sense of being connected with the ancient world, of having stumbled upon a secret that could outlast generations. This memory must have been drawn back into his mind by the discomfort of his throat. It was curious, but when you looked into the past it always seemed to be a particular physical detail that persisted in the memory. It was the details of daily life that clung like burrs to the mind, and it was against them that the most important facts struggled to get lodged. He had often thought later how it was that that incident had so deeply engraved itself on his memory, even after the passage of decades. Perhaps it was because the soft, fleshy object had for a moment given him a glimpse into the beauty of the natural world, a fleeting sensation of connection with something greater than himself, something that was alive and growing. In the harsh, mechanized world of Oceania, such moments were rare and precious. They were like tiny breaches in the fortress of the Party, through which the forbidden truth had a chance to shine. And in that truth, Winston believed, lay the hope for the future, the possibility of a world where humanity could flourish once more, free from the oppressive yoke of Big Brother and the Party's relentless control. As the Physical Jerks continued, Winston's mind drifted further into these thoughts, a dangerous but irresistible escape from the present reality. He knew that such musings were futile and potentially perilous, yet he couldn't help but cling to them as a lifeline in the vast, oppressive sea of the Party's regime. The struggle for freedom, for truth, was a solitary one, and in moments like these, Winston felt the weight of that solitude more acutely than ever. Yet, even in his darkest moments, a flicker of hope persisted, a belief that somewhere, somehow, the human spirit could prevail against the forces of tyranny and oppression. It was this belief that kept him going, that fueled his defiance in the face of overwhelming odds. And so, as the Physical Jerks came to an end and the class dispersed, Winston straightened his back, squared his shoulders, and prepared once again to face the world of Oceania, determined to hold onto his fragile dreams of a better future.

en_results: completion The Ministry of Plenty’s certainly done a good job this year,” he said with a knowing shake
en_results_raw: completion The Ministry of Plenty’s certainly done a good job this year,” he said with a knowing shake of his head, though his words dripped with irony. The Ministry of Plenty was notorious for its contradictory name; it was responsible for artificial scarcity and rationing, ensuring that the Party maintained control over the populace through hunger. Winston, like many others, had grown up with the Ministry's propaganda, which claimed to provide abundance while delivering the exact opposite. The telescreen in the corner of his cramped apartment blared out the latest figures on chocolate and synthetic gin production, both of which were supposedly at record highs. Yet, Winston knew better. He had seen the real numbers, the ones that didn't make it onto the telescreen. The Ministry of Plenty's 'good job' was a cruel joke, a testament to the Party's mastery of doublethink and the manipulation of truth. Despite the hardships, Winston couldn't help but feel a flicker of rebellion. The Party might control the present, but could they control the past and future as thoroughly? He scribbled in his diary, a dangerous act of rebellion, "The Ministry of Plenty is a lie. The Party starves us while claiming abundance." The words were a small act of defiance, a tiny crack in the facade of the Party's control. But in Oceania, even the smallest cracks could be dangerous.

en_first_half: He remembered how once he had been walking down a crowded street when a tremendous shout of hundreds of voices—women’s voices—had burst from a side street a little way ahead. It was a great formidable cry of anger and despair, a deep, loud “Oh-o-o-o-oh!” that went humming on like the reverberation of a bell. His heart had leapt. It’s started! he had thought. A riot! The proles are breaking loose at last! When he had reached the spot it was to see a mob of two or three hundred women crowding round the stalls of a street market, with faces as tragic as though they had been the doomed passengers on a sinking ship. But at this moment the general despair broke down into a multitude of individual quarrels. It appeared that one of the stalls had been selling tin saucepans. They were wretched, flimsy
en_second_half: things, but cooking pots of any kind were always difficult to get. Now the supply had unexpectedly given out. The successful women, bumped and jostled by the rest, were trying to make off with their saucepans while dozens of others clamored round the stall, accusing the stallkeeper of favoritism and of having more saucepans somewhere in reserve. There was a fresh outburst of yells. Two bloated women, one of them with her hair coming down, had got hold of the same saucepan and were trying to tear it out of one another’s hands. For a moment they were both tugging, and then the handle came off. Winston watched them disgustedly. And yet, just for a moment, what almost frightening power had sounded in that cry from only a few hundred throats! Why was it that they could never shout like that about anything that mattered?

en_first_half: FROM SOMEWHERE at the bottom of a passage the smell of roasting coffee—real coffee, not Victory Coffee—came floating out into the street. Winston paused involuntarily. For perhaps two seconds
en_second_half: he was back in the half-forgotten world of his childhood. Then a door banged, seeming to cut off the smell as abruptly as though it had been a sound.
en_results: The aroma was so rich and potent that it seemed to wrap around him, drawing him in with a promise of warmth and comfort. It was a scent from another time,
en_results_raw: The aroma was so rich and potent that it seemed to wrap around him, drawing him in with a promise of warmth and comfort. It was a scent from another time, a time before the world had been plunged into the perpetual coldness of war and the Party's relentless control. Winston's mind drifted back to those distant memories, to a life before the omnipresent telescreens, the daily Two Minutes Hate, and the pervasive fear of the Thought Police. The coffee smell was a siren call to a past where individuality was not a crime, where one could indulge in simple pleasures without suspicion or guilt. It was a reminder of a world that Winston had known only in fragments, through fleeting dreams and half-remembered conversations. He stood there, momentarily lost in the sensory reverie, his heart aching with a longing for a reality that no longer existed. The coffee smell was a tease, a cruel reminder of what had been lost, and yet, it also held a glimmer of hope—a whisper of resistance against the oppressive regime. Winston knew that even the smallest acts of rebellion, like the clandestine brewing of real coffee, were dangerous. They were a defiance against the Party's relentless homogenization of life, a silent protest against the erasure of personal desires and memories. Yet, in that brief moment, standing there in the street, the smell of real coffee was a beacon of humanity, a testament to the indomitable spirit that still flickered within him, despite the Party's best efforts to extinguish it.

en_first_half: “Steamer” was a nickname which, for some reason, the proles applied to rocket bombs. Winston promptly flung himself on his face. The proles were nearly always right when they gave you a warning of this kind. They seemed to possess some kind of instinct which told them several seconds in advance when a rocket
en_second_half: was coming, although the rockets supposedly traveled faster than sound. Winston clasped his forearms about his head. There was a roar that seemed to make the pavement heave; a shower of light objects pattered onto his back. When he stood up he found that he was covered with fragments of glass from the nearest window.
en_results: was coming. It was perhaps not more than two minutes after the flash that the first rocket bomb struck the Ministry of Truth. There was a deafening roar, the building shook violently, and an enormous cloud of black smoke shot up into the sky. Winston felt himself hurled across the floor, and everything went black. When
en_results_raw: was coming. It was perhaps not more than two minutes after the flash that the first rocket bomb struck the Ministry of Truth. There was a deafening roar, the building shook violently, and an enormous cloud of black smoke shot up into the sky. Winston felt himself hurled across the floor, and everything went black. When he came to himself he was lying face downwards in the rubble, half buried, the broken end of a beam pinning him down. His first act was to drag himself free, with a violent wrench, and then he staggered to his feet and stood blinking stupidly at a world which had turned suddenly dark and unfamiliar. The building had collapsed at the edge, not right above him. There was still a roof, or what had been a roof, two or three metres above his head, but it was all askew, sticking out at crazy angles, and showering down bricks, mortar, and plaster. Beside him lay a chunk of something a couple of metres across, probably a portion of the fallen wall, with a jagged hole in it. And sticking out of this hole was a long, gleaming object which Winston instantly recognized as the tail of a rocket bomb. The bomb itself was not in sight. He wondered vaguely whether it had already exploded. Probably not, because he was alive. But it must be close by, buried in the debris. He had a queer feeling that it might explode at any moment, and yet it remained there, a potential catastrophe, so close to him that he could have touched it with his hand if he reached out. He stood gazing stupidly at it, the dust and the smell of rubble in his nostrils, the roar of the rocket bombs and the shouts of the bombers seeming to approach and recede in a confusion of sound. He realized that he was in shock, that the shock was fading out of his mind, that he was coming back into touch with reality. He noticed that his arm was bleeding freely where the jagged edge of the beam had scored it. His overalls were in rags, his shoes had been blown off, and there was a large lump coming up on his forehead. But at this moment those were only minor symptoms. The serious thing was the bomb. He began to think more clearly and to plan. The first thing was to get out of the shelter of the fallen building before the rockets came back. The bombers would be wheeling overhead within a minute or two, and you could never predict where they would drop their next load. He forced himself into a stumbling run, half-staggered, half-ran, out into an open space, not stopping until he was a safe distance from the building. Then he turned round and looked back. The Ministry of Truth had collapsed as though a giant hand had picked it up and crushed it. The dome roof, a little way away from the main structure, still stood, but it was already cracking at the seams. The whole of the south face had completely disappeared. Winston gazed at it, fascinated, almost forgetting the danger he was in. He realized that he had never in his life seen a building destroyed. A rocket bomb was evidently a far more terrible weapon than he had imagined. In the meantime the bombers were circling in the distance, and there was a sudden roar as another bomb dropped with a crash on some unsuspecting street. Winston ran a few steps this way and that, just enough to make sure that no fragment of bomb would fall on him, and then halted and stood watching the devastation. The Ministry of Truth had collapsed as though it had been built of cardboard. But what of the bomb that was still buried under the rubble? It might go off at any moment, might already be emitting deadly rays of energy. He must get away from it as quickly as possible. Within twenty years at the most, he reflected, the huge and simple question, “Was life better before the Revolution than it is now?” would have ceased once and for all to be answerable. en_second_half: from the ancient world were incapable of comparing one age with another. They remembered a million useless things, a quarrel with a workmate, a hunt for a lost bicycle pump, the expression on a long-dead sister’s face, the swirls of dust on a windy morning seventy years ago; but all the relevant facts were outside the range of their vision. They were like the ant, which can see small objects but not large ones. And when memory failed and written records were falsified—when that happened, the claim of the Party to have improved the conditions of human life had got to be accepted, because there did not exist, and never again could exist, any standard against which it could be tested.

He stopped short. It was exactly the picture that had been forming in his mind in the last five minutes. The old man, the room with the slop bucket, the smell of urine and stale beer, the wrinkled cheeks of the prostitute against the grained wood of the bedstead, and the glass paperweight with its central bubble of colored glass – it all fitted together, and the final piece of the pattern was the portrait of Mr. Jones, the man whose memory was being abolished. He stood dead still, in the crowded street, with the blood thudding in his ears. The pieces were falling into place, the original picture was re-forming itself out of fragments. In the end the Party would announce that two and two made five, and you would have to believe it. It was inevitable that they should make that claim sooner or later: the logic of their position demanded it. Not merely the validity of experience, but the very existence of external reality was tacitly denied by their philosophy. The heresy of heresies was common sense. And what was terrifying was not that they would kill you for thinking otherwise, but that they might be right. For, after all, how do we know that two and two make four? Or that the force of gravity works? Or that the past is unchangeable? If the Party could thrust its logic into your guts by means of a sledgehammer, then surely it was possible that they could make you deny the evidence of your own senses. But it was no use getting frightened by that thought, you could not control the physical world any more than you could control the past. He decided to go back to the café and drink another half-liter of Victory Gin.

Entre ellos, un diario antiguo, cubierto de grietas pero aún legible, llamaba la atención. La primera página contenía una fecha: 1945. La escritura era delicada pero firme, indicando un esfuerzo consciente por mantener un registro de los acontecimientos. A medida que se leía, se descubría una historia de supervivencia, de amor perdido y de esperanza reencontrada. El dueño de la tienda, un anciano con ojos que brillaban a pesar de la vejez, observaba a cualquiera que se atreviera a entrar. "Todo tiene su historia", solía decir, con una sonrisa mística. Y así, entre los relicarios de un pasado olvidado, se encontraba la verdadera valía de la tienda: no en los objetos físicos, sino en las historias que contaban.

en_results_raw: limb. He had never before seen a person with a wounded face. The contrast of that moment overwhelmed him for a flicker. It was as though the texture of this sudden world, with all its cruelty and its precarious human beauty, had changed before his eyes. He felt an impulse to reach out and squeeze the woman's hand, to assure himself of her reality, of her pain and her courage. But instead, he turned abruptly and walked back to the telescreen, knowing that any such gesture would be madness. The bullet had been dodged, but the danger was far from over. The Party's reach was long, and its memory was infallible. He had to be careful, more careful than ever. The telescreen watched, and it was always watching. Winston's mind raced with the implications of what had just happened. He needed to document this event, to capture the moment before the Party could erase it from his memory or alter the narrative. He had to find a way to communicate this truth, to remind himself and perhaps others of the humanity that still flickered beneath the oppression. The diary, his secret refuge, beckoned him. He would write about this encounter, about the woman's pain and his own conflicted emotions. It was a risk, but one he felt compelled to take. The Party demanded absolute loyalty and conformity, but Winston refused to let his humanity be extinguished. He would resist, in whatever small ways he could, and the diary was his weapon. As he sat down to write, he felt a surge of defiance. The Party could control the present and the past, but they could not control his thoughts, not completely. In this act of rebellion, of recording his truth, Winston found a glimmer of hope. It was a fragile hope, easily snuffed out, but it was enough to sustain him for now. The struggle against the Party was endless, but it was a struggle worth fighting. For in the act of remembering and recording, Winston held onto a piece of his soul, a piece that the Party could never fully claim.

I value my time, my resources, and my peace of mind too much to squander them on ventures that lack substance and purpose. Moreover, taking risks should be informed by careful consideration and a solid understanding of the potential outcomes. It’s about making calculated decisions rather than impulsive ones. en_first_half: “You will have heard rumors of the existence of the Brotherhood. No doubt you have formed your own picture of it. You have imagined, probably, a huge underworld of conspirators, meeting secretly in cellars, scribbling messages on walls, recognizing one another by code words or by special movements of the hand. Nothing of the kind exists. The members of the Brotherhood have no way of recognizing one another, and it is impossible for any one member to be aware of the identity of more than a very few others. Goldstein himself, if he fell into the hands of the Thought Police, could not give them a complete list of members, or any information that would lead them to a complete list. No such list exists. The Brotherhood cannot be wiped out because it is not an organization in the ordinary sense. Nothing holds it together except an idea which is indestructible. You will never have anything to sustain you except the idea. You will get no comradeship and no encouragement. When finally you are caught, you will
en_second_half: get no help. We never help our members. At most, when it is absolutely necessary that someone should be silenced, we are occasionally able to smuggle a razor blade into a prisoner’s cell. You will have to get used to living without results and without hope. You will work for a while, you will be caught, you will confess, and then you will die. Those are the only results that you will ever see. There is no possibility that any perceptible change will happen within our own lifetime. We are the dead. Our only true life is in the future. We shall take part in it as handfuls of dust and splinters of bone. But how far away that future may be, there is no knowing. It might be a thousand years. At present nothing is possible except to extend the area of sanity little by little. We cannot act collectively. We can only spread our knowledge outwards from individual to individual, generation after generation. In the face of the Thought Police there is no other way.”

en_results_raw: inconspicuous about him was the detail that he had a remarkable set of muscles under his overalls. Winston noticed that despite his unassuming appearance, the man moved with a certain grace and poise that suggested a background of physical training. His eyes, however, were what truly set him apart. They were cold, calculating, and seemed to pierce through anyone who dared to meet his gaze. It was as if they held a secret, a knowledge of something sinister, which made Winston uneasy. The man was escorted to a chair opposite Winston, and without a word, he sat down, his posture perfect, his expression unreadable. The room fell silent, the tension palpable. Winston couldn't shake off the feeling that this new prisoner was not just another unfortunate soul caught in the Party's web, but perhaps something more—a wolf in sheep's clothing, or a spy with a mission. The interrogator, sensing the shift in atmosphere, cleared his throat and began the session, but Winston's mind was racing, trying to piece together the significance of this newcomer. The man's presence was a puzzle, and Winston knew that in the world they lived in, every piece mattered, every detail could be a clue to survival or betrayal. As the interrogation proceeded, Winston found himself more attentive to the new prisoner than to the questions being hurled at him. He was searching for a hint, a slip of the tongue, anything that might reveal the truth about this enigmatic figure. The session dragged on, but Winston's focus never wavered. He knew that in the oppressive regime they lived under, appearances could be deceiving, and sometimes, the most unassuming individuals held the most dangerous secrets.

O'Brien's words echoed in Winston's mind, a haunting reminder of the futility of resistance. The Party's grip was unyielding, its reach infinite. Winston turned away, his spirit crushed, knowing that the truth O'Brien spoke was irrefutable. The Party had won, and there was no escape. The telescreen loomed in the corner, a constant reminder of the omnipresent gaze of Big Brother. Winston's heart ached with the weight of his defeat, yet he understood the inevitability of it all. The Party had reshaped reality to its liking, and in this new world, resistance was not just futile—it was unimaginable. He walked back to his small, dimly lit room, the oppressive atmosphere of the Ministry seeping into his bones. The Party's victory was complete, and Winston Smith, once a man of defiance, was now just another cog in the machine, his spirit broken, his will extinguished. The future was bleak, a never-ending cycle of oppression and control, and Winston could do nothing but accept it. The Party had him, and it would always have him, for there was no escape from the iron grip of its totalitarian regime.

In the old days, before we had this beautiful new technology, it was necessary to transfer the prisoner to a special room for treatment. But in the interests of humanity it has been arranged that the minimum number of prisoners should undergo the process; in any case, it is unnecessary. The second blow was a little more severe. “That,” said O’Brien, “was fifty. You are feeling that, are you not?” Winston made no answer. “That was fifty-three. This,” said O’Brien, “is the worst endurable pain. I will come back in a few minutes. Meanwhile, I should like you to continue with your composition.” He went out. For a while Winston clung to his sanity. He told himself, over and over, that he was in the Ministry of Love, that he was in danger, that reality existed, that O’Brien was an enemy. The horrible thing about the Two Minutes Hate was not that one was obliged to act a part, but that it was impossible to avoid joining in. Now, in quite a different way, the same thing was happening to him again. Only this time it was not the shouting of a crowd, or the roar of a gun, that impelled him to shout at the top of his voice. It was fear, pure fear, and hatred of the face on the screen. Somehow it was as though the terrors of the Party had taken on flesh and become visible. He knew, of course, that in the physical sense the picture was not real. It was only a creation of the tele-screen. But that was not the point. The tele-screen was real, it was a piece of solid matter. You could put your hand on it. But that was not the point either. The point was that it could thrust its arm right into the heart of you and freeze you with fright.

La realidad le parecía una tela delicada, intermitente, que a veces se deshacía en fragmentos confusos. Winston se preguntaba si, de algún modo, su lucha era en vano, si realmente podía cambiar algo en un mundo diseñado para controlar cada pensamiento, cada gesto. La lealtad a la verdad, a la memoria, se convirtió en su única fuente de esperanza, aunque sabía que tal aspiración podría ser fatal. La desaparición de los hechos históricos, la manipulación constante de la información, todo ello creaba un vacío en su alma, un vacío que solo la verdad podía llenar. Pero ¿qué era verdad en un mundo donde la realidad era lo que el Partido decía que era? Winston luchaba no solo por su propia supervivencia, sino por la supervivencia de la humanidad misma, por la posibilidad de que algún día la humanidad pudiera respirar de nuevo en un mundo libre de la opresión. La lucha era eterna, y cada pequeño logro, cada pensamiento libre, era un acto de resistencia contra el torrente opresivo del Partido. La desesperanza a menudo lo envolvía, pero también sentía un fervor inextinguible por la justicia y la libertad. En este mundo distópico, Winston era un faro de resistencia, un recordatorio constante de que, a pesar de todo, la lucha por la verdad perduraba.

en_first_half: “THERE ARE THREE STAGES in your reintegration,” said O’Brien. “There is learning, there is understanding,
en_second_half: and there is acceptance. It is time for you to enter upon the second stage.”
en_results: acceptance. The first stage, learning, involves absorbing the new reality of
en_results_raw: acceptance. The first stage, learning, involves absorbing the new reality of your situation. It's about familiarizing yourself with the rules, the environment, and the expectations placed upon you. This stage can be disorienting as you grapple with the stark differences from what you once knew. Understanding, the second stage, is where you begin to comprehend the deeper implications of your new reality. It's not just about knowing the facts, but also about interpreting their meaning and their impact on your life. This stage often involves emotional processing as you come to terms with your changed circumstances. Acceptance, the final stage, is where you fully embrace your new reality. It's about reconciling your past with your present, finding peace within your new environment, and actively participating in your new life. This stage is marked by a sense of belonging and purpose, where you no longer resist but instead integrate your new identity into your sense of self. Each stage is crucial, and moving through them is a journey of transformation and growth.

La exploración de estas gigantes celestes ha llevado a los seres humanos a comprender mejor el cosmos y su historia. All day, with little spurts of excitement, the thought of a smashing defeat in Africa had been in and out of his mind. He seemed actually to see the Eurasian army swarming across the never-broken frontier and pouring down into the tip of Africa like a column of ants. Why had it not been possible to outflank them in some way? The outline of the West African coast stood out vividly in his mind. He picked up the white knight and moved it across the board. There was the proper spot. Even while he saw the black
en_second_half: horde racing southward he saw another force, mysteriously assembled, suddenly planted in their rear, cutting their communications by land and sea. He felt that by willing it he was bringing that other force into existence. But it was necessary to act quickly. If they could get control of the whole of Africa, if they had airfields and submarine bases at the Cape, it would cut Oceania in two. It might mean anything: defeat, breakdown, the redivision of the world, the destruction of the Party! He drew a deep breath. An extraordinary medley of feelings—but it was not a medley, exactly; rather it was successive layers of feeling, in which one could not say which layer was undermost—struggled inside him.

It was as though the whole continent were swarming with a monstrous beetle. He perceived that in moments of danger the continuity of life not only persisted but the heart of it, so to speak, expanded. The danger was all in the future, the present only contained the thrill and the excitement of watching the black and red lines sweeping back and forth, sweeping away the green of the forests, erasing the blue of the rivers, trampling down the pink of the lakes. Mere nature existed only in the background, a landscape on which history marched. The endless warfare of the past was only a pattern, a colour scheme in which the blacks and the reds and the greens formed part of the decoration of the earth. In the mind of the Party, what was written in the sky would always remain true. Even the stars were Oceania, and nothing was outside its boundaries. The rocket bombs which fell daily on London were never an indication that Oceania was in danger; they were a reminder to the inhabitants that the war was still going on, and that the danger was all in some other part of the world. The frontiers melted away and shuffled into new patterns; the map of the world changed continually, and no one could quite remember where the decisive battle had been fought, or who had been the enemy. All that was needed was that the hierarchical structure should be preserved, and the two aims of the Party: war and the protection of the Party.

en_first_half: It must have been about a month before she disappeared. It was a moment of reconciliation, when the nagging hunger in his belly was forgotten and his earlier affection for her had temporarily revived. He remembered the day well, a pelting, drenching day when the water streamed down the window pane and the light indoors was too dull to read by. The boredom of the two children in the dark, cramped bedroom became unbearable. Winston whined and grizzled, made futile demands for food, fretted about the room, pulling everything out of place and kicking the wainscoting until the neighbors banged on the wall, while the younger child wailed intermittently. In the end his mother said, “Now be good, and I’ll buy you a toy. A lovely toy—you’ll love it”; and then she had gone out in the rain, to a little general shop which was still sporadically open near by, and come
en_second_half: back with a cardboard box containing an outfit of Snakes and Ladders. He could still remember the smell of the damp cardboard. It was a miserable outfit. The board was cracked and the tiny wooden dice were so ill-cut that they would hardly lie on their sides. Winston looked at the thing sulkily and without interest. But then his mother lit a piece of candle and they sat down on the floor to play. Soon he was wildly excited and shouting with laughter as the tiddlywinks climbed hopefully up the ladders and then came slithering down the snakes again, almost back to the starting point. They played eight games, winning four each. His tiny sister, too young to understand what the game was about, had sat propped up against a bolster, laughing because the others were laughing. For a whole afternoon they had all been happy together, as in his earlier childhood.

El aburrimiento de los dos niños en la triste habitación era insoportable. Winston gimoteaba, pedía inútilmente que le dieran de comer, recorría la habitación revolviéndolo todo y dando patadas hasta que los vecinos tuvieron que protestar. es_second_half: a pesar de la lluvia para ir a unos almacenes que estaban abiertos a esa hora y volvió con una caja de cartón conteniendo el juego llamado «De las serpientes y las escaleras». Era muy modesto. El cartón estaba rasgado y los pequeños dados de madera, tan mal cortados que apenas se sostenían. Winston recordaba el olor a humedad del cartón. Había mirado el juego de mal humor.
